title: 109_s2308
content: The Mine Safety and Health Act of 2006 is also known as the "Mine Safety and Health Act." It aims to improve mandatory health and safety standards. The Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 is amended to include improved mandatory health and safety standards for all coal or other mines, such as strategically locating oxygen stations and implementing wireless emergency tracking devices. The Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 is amended to include requirements for wireless emergency tracking and communication devices for miners in underground coal or other mines. Operators must provide miners with tracking devices for rescue purposes and require them to carry communication devices. Additionally, communication during rescue operations should be limited to those involved, and secondary telephone services should be available in designated areas. Operators in underground coal or other mines must provide secondary telephone service or equivalent communication facilities for miners working in designated areas to ensure communication with surface or rescue personnel in case of emergencies. This includes reports, plan reviews, and citations. The Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 is amended to require the Secretary to conduct interviews with miners regarding accidents without the operator present. Regulations will be established for investigating accidents in mines and holding related hearings. The Secretary must submit reports on investigations or reviews of accidents to specific Senate and House committees. Additionally, a quarterly review of ventilation systems and safety plans is mandated under the Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977. The Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 requires operators to review their system, methane, and dust control plans every 3 months. Additionally, operators must take steps to address violations within 24 hours of receiving a citation. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Mine Safety and Health Act to establish an emergency call center for all mine operations, staffed 24/7. The center will have an updated contact list for all mines. Increased penalties and user fees under the Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977, with a civil penalty of up to $500,000 for flagrant violations defined as reckless or repeated failures to address known safety violations causing death. The Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 has increased penalties for flagrant violations, with civil penalties now up to $500,000 for reckless or repeated failures leading to death or serious bodily injury. This includes adjustments such as raising fines from $5,000 to $55,000, $25,000 to $250,000, $50,000 to $500,000, $1,000 to $20,000, and $10,000 to $100,000 in different subsections. Any operator who fails to inform the Secretary of a disaster relating to a coal or other mine within the 15-minute period following the occurrence of the disaster shall be subject to a civil penalty of not less than $100,000. The Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 has increased penalties for violations, with fines now ranging from $10,000 to $500,000 for serious health or safety violations. Habitual violators face fines of at least $20,000, and operators must also pay a $100 user fee for each penalty imposed. The Administration account will be used to fund activities such as training, research, rescue teams, and technical support for miner safety. The Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 prohibits reducing fines for flagrant or habitual violations. SEC. 6. MANDATORY HEALTH AND SAFETY TRAINING. Amends the Federal Mine Safety and Health Act of 1977 to require miners to receive training on wireless communications devices and participate in emergency rescue drills.
